title: EIP ( draft ) SelfDestruct Waiting List ( a Garbage Filter for Statically Referred Common Libraries )
body:
## Preamble

    EIP: <to be assigned>
    Title: SelfDestruct waiting List ( a Garbage Filter for 'Statically Referred Common Libraries' )
    Author: ghasshee@gmail.com
    Type: Meta
    Status: Draft
    Created: 2017-11-17


## Simple Summary

To be a common web tool, Ethereum would have various kinds of safety nets which guarantee the data, especially that of library contracts, is safely kept. In this issue, I would like to propose one kind of safety net, which is `SelfDestruct Waiting List`. When `SELFDESTRUCT` is called, the contract will get held by the list in some term `t`.

## Abstract

We have 2 new Lists, `ListOfReferrers` and `SelfDestructWaitingList`.

The `ListOfReferrers` is a list of sets, each set is named with a contract address e.g. `A`.
the set `A` is a set of contract addresses which statically call contract `A` directly.
* Every time a contract is deployed, we add its static reference information to the list.
* If contract `A` executes `SELFDESTRUCT`,  then add `A` to the `SelfDestructWaitingList`.
Then for all member `x` of the `SelfDestructWaitingList`,
  - make a new list `AllReferrers(x)` which lists all direct and indirect referrers,
  - and if `AllReferrers(x)` ⊆ `SelfDestructWaitingList` then `SELFDESTRUCT` `x` and clean `x` completely from both lists else do nothing.
  - After the term `t` has passed, Remove `A` from `SelfDestructWaitingList`.

## Motivation

The problem is we do not have a proper `Garbage Filter`.
This is an attempt to formalize how to deal with what is going to be garbage.

## Specification

e.g. 1
~~~
let ListOfReferrers(A) = {}

if contract 'A' which statically refers only contract 'A' is deployed, then
ListOfReferrers(A) += {}  // Do not include itself to Referrers

So if SELFDESTRUCT 'A' is called,
AllRefers(A) = {} and 'A' self-destructs immediately,
and clean 'A' from both lists completely.
~~~

e.g. 2
~~~
let ListOfReferrers(A) = {}, ListOfReferrers(B) = {}, ListOfReferrers(C) = {}
if contract 'A' which statically refers 'B' is deployed, then ListOfReferrers(B) += A
if contract 'B' which statically refers 'C' is deployed, then ListOfReferrers(C) += B
if contract 'C' which statically refers 'A' is deployed, then ListOfReferrers(A) += C

now the whole List is like;
ListOfReferrers = {
    A : {C},
    B : {A},
    C : {B}
}

then call SELFDESTRUCTs.
let SelfDestructWaitingList = {}

if SELFDESTRUCT 'A' is called
then SelfDestructWaitingList += A and make AllRefers(A) = {B,C}.
Then 'for all x ∈ SelfDestructWaitingList, if AllReferrers(x) ⊆ SelfDestructWaitingList then SELFDESTRUCT x else do nothing' is executed.
For now nothing happens.

if SELFDESTRUCT 'B' is called
then SelfDestructWaitingList += B (so = {A,B})
and make AllReferes(A) = {B,C} and AllReferes(B) = {C,A}.
Then 'for all x ∈ SelfDestructWaitingList, if AllReferrers(x) ⊆ SelfDestructWaitingList then SELFDESTRUCT x else do nothing' is executed.
For now nothing happens.

if SELFDESTRUCT 'C' is called
then SelfDestructWaitingList += C (so = {A,B,C})
and make AllReferes(A) = {B,C}, AllReferes(B) = {C,A}, and AllReferres(C) = {A,B}.
Then 'for all x ∈ SelfDestructWaitingList, if AllReferrers(x) ⊆ SelfDestructWaitingList then SELFDESTRUCT x else do nothing' is executed.
Now all A, B, C self-destruct.
And remove A,B,C from SelfDestructWaitingList.
And clean A,B,C from ListOfReferrers completely.
~~~

e.g. 3
~~~
if contract A dynamically refers from contract AA to contract AZ
then do nothing.

So if SELFDESTRUCT 'AA' then 'AA' self-destructs immediately and clean.
~~~

e.g. 3 shows that this is a limited safety net only for statically referred common library.

## Rationale

I think we all who will use library contracts on Turing completeness decentralized consensus machines in the future might have potential to have responsibility for the vulnerability which anyone could cause at libraries on such a new technology.

## Backwards Compatibility

I am not sure but this might need a hard fork because of creating new two database. I would like to keep them in another place, e.g. `~/.ethereum/gf/` ( `gf` denotes `garbage filter` ) at the first implementation of this issue.

## Test Cases

Just I thought that it could be suitable with ⊂ rather than with ⊆.

## Implementation

## Copyright
Perhaps or maybe, Copyright and related rights waived via [CC0](https://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/).
You may want to clarify what you mean by "refer". It may be hard to define this as a contract can dynamically refer to any address and call any addresses code.

Thanks. It seems the first problem. 
We could start from assuming references are static and we could develop it.
Let's consider it.

I mean "referring" as "(a contract) calling (another contract)".
Right now this could be limited to static references.
So the title might be modified to 
"a suicide filter for Common Library which is statically called by some contracts"
I added e.g. 3 ( `IF` a contract is dynamically referred `THEN` do nothing )

Suicide, or politically correct “self destruct”, is one of those features that should never be there, because it breaks fundamental principal of immutability of smart contract's code.  The code of deployed contract may not be changed in general (which might actually be very useful in many cases), but may be wiped out (which is not useful at all but is actually extremely dangerous).  It also breaks the rule that contract's code is executed every time ether is being sent to the contract and contract may always reject ether transferred to it by reverting the transaction.
Just avoiding using self destruct and printing at compile time bold warning about self destruct usage would be much simpler and much better protection from accidentally killed contracts.

I think it might be a good point since I do not know how to motivate that full nodes should keep the DB small right now. This could be the restarting point of discussions about something similar to GC in terms of blockchain technology. ( I might remember someone had mentioned on gitter 'why not have GC?' and another man had answered 'It might be too early to discuss about it.' before, maybe about 1 or 2 years ago. )

I have not read the detailed spec yet, just trying to get the concept, which is that if a contract SUICIDEs the suicide does not have any effect until there are no static references to the contract?
If so, does your algorithm handle circular references?  And what about static references made after the contract has committed suicide?

Maybe I have considered the circulation problem with `e.g.2`.
Once contract suicide has finished, the static reference to it is, I think, a kind of null pointer ( it really lacks the referred object ).

`e.g.2` shows that
if `A,B,C` compose a simple directed reference triangle, 
then there won't happen suicides until all of them call `SUICIDE`.
OK.  I've written GCs for computer memory, but this is different, as it's automatic collection of manually deleted objects.
Thanks. I have just thought I should rename to `preGC` or to `Garbage Filter`.
I don't think actual garbage collection, as usually defined, is possible.
EOA?

I mean `Externally Owned Account` with EOA.
EOA also refers contracts when he/she wants to refer and we cannot expect when and who will, so I agree that real GC cannot happen in ethereum. 
I also think, if possible, we would have chance to be taught much more about GC, which might be a different topic or not.

Right.  Garbage collection operates in a closed world, so you can know for sure that an object can no longer be referenced.  EOAs break that assumption.  The motivation here seems to be making it possible to write contracts that call other contracts with a guarantee that they won't SUICIDE out from under you.
Thanks. It could sound right.

Of course other way to do that is to copy the contract you want to call.

And the alternative EIP to do that is to deprecate SUICIDE completely.
What does `deprecate SUICIDE` mean in your comment ?
Hard fork that says after some block number SUICIDE will be an invalid instruction.

An anti-SELFDESTRUCT EIP does sound pretty noble, but deprecating SELFDESTRUCT all-together (invalidating transactions that use the SELFDESTRUCT opcode) sounds dangerous because then functions in contracts that currently work will make the transaction invalid. Hard forks shouldn't restrict functionality of existing contracts. More realistic IMO is leaving it a valid opcode, leaving the functionality for it to forward ETH, but still have the contract be usable and not removing it from the state.

The follow-up question is whether we would want previously selfdestructed contracts to be resurrected.
It would remain valid for older contracts.  Resurrecting previously suicided contracts is under consideration, but it's not clear it can be made safe.
Would it be possible to reword this EIP to use SELFDESTRUCT, 'self destruct' etc. (https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/blob/master/EIPS/eip-6.md)
Thanks. I will try it.

There has been no activity on this issue for two months. It will be closed in a week if no further activity occurs. If you would like to move this EIP forward, please respond to any outstanding feedback or add a comment indicating that you have addressed all required feedback and are ready for a review.
This issue was closed due to inactivity. If you are still pursuing it, feel free to reopen it and respond to any feedback or request a review in a comment.
